verses.text: A wise judge will instruct his people, and the rule of the prudent is well-ordered.
verses.comment: This verse opens with the idea that wisdom among rulers leads to good order. Theological tradition often sees this as reflecting God's own perfect governance (see Rom. 13:1).

verses.text: As the judge of his people is, so also are his officers; and what kind of ruler a city is, such are all who dwell in it.
verses.comment: Leadership shapes a community. In the spiritual sense, Christ as Head shapes the church (Col. 1:18).

verses.text: An unwise king destroys his people, but cities will be inhabited through the understanding of the rulers.
verses.comment: Wisdom from leaders ensures the flourishing of society; this points to the value of spiritual authority guided by God's wisdom.

verses.text: Authority over the earth is in the hand of the Lord, and at the right time he will raise up the right person for it.
verses.comment: The text emphasizes God's sovereignty over human rulers (cf. Dan. 4:17), foreshadowing the authority of Christ.

verses.text: The success of a man is in the Lord's hand, and it is He who gives honor to the lawgiver.
verses.comment: All leadership, honor, and law come from God, preparing the way for Christ who is the fulfillment of both Law and Kingship.

verses.text: Do not bear resentment against your neighbor for any wrong, and do nothing by acts of violence.
verses.comment: This anticipates Jesus’ teaching on forgiveness and non-retaliation (Matt. 5:44).

verses.text: Pride is hateful before the Lord and mankind; and both is injustice brought about by wickedness.
verses.comment: Pride leads to injustice—a theme throughout the Old and New Testaments, directly opposed by Christ’s humility (Phil. 2:8).

verses.text: Because of unrighteous dealings, violence, and greed, kingdoms are transferred from one nation to another.
verses.comment: The rise and fall of nations is linked to justice—a theme developed further in the prophets.

verses.text: Why are dust and ashes proud? There is nothing more disgraceful than a proud person. The Lord will overthrow their glory.
verses.comment: Humility is essential; pride is contrary to our origin and destiny.

verses.text: A long illness brings the physician low; even a king today will die tomorrow.
verses.comment: All must face mortality, king or commoner—pointing us toward the hope of resurrection (1 Cor. 15:22).

verses.text: When someone dies, all their actions cease, and their works come to an end.
verses.comment: The finality of death shows the necessity to live righteously and prepare for judgment (Heb. 9:27).

verses.text: Pride was not created for man, nor fierce anger for those born of a woman.
verses.comment: Pride and wrath have no place in human nature, echoing Christ’s teachings on humility and meekness.

verses.text: What kind of seed is honored? The seed of man. Those who break the law are a dishonored seed.
verses.comment: Human dignity comes from following God’s law; breaking it leads to disgrace. This underlies the need for the new covenant.

verses.text: A leader among his brothers is honored, and those who fear the Lord are held in high esteem by him.
verses.comment: Respect is given by true reverence of God, not by earthly status.

verses.text: Whether rich, honored, or poor, their glory is the fear of the Lord.
verses.comment: Reverence for God makes all equal, foreshadowing the spiritual unity of God’s people.

verses.text: It is not right to despise a poor man who has understanding, nor is it proper to honor a sinner.
verses.comment: Wisdom and virtue, not worldly status, determine honor before God.

verses.text: The prince, judge, and mighty are honored, but none is greater than the one who fears the Lord.
verses.comment: All positions are surpassed by the true wisdom found in fearing God—a theme fulfilled in Christ (Matt. 12:42).

verses.text: Free people, servants, the poor, and the rich have their boast in the fear of the Lord.
verses.comment: True dignity comes only from right relationship with God, not social class—a teaching the church carries forward.

verses.text: It is not right to despise an intelligent poor man or to honor a sinful man.
verses.comment: Wisdom and righteousness, not richness, merit true honor.

verses.text: The ruler, judge, and the mighty are honored, but the wise man is honored even more than these.
verses.comment: Exalts the pursuit of wisdom above all ranks and statuses—a recurring biblical theme (cf. Solomon).

verses.text: With the wisdom of the humble, the Lord is pleased, and he crowns them with eternal joy.
verses.comment: God’s favor rests on humility, culminating in the promises found in Jesus’ teaching on the Beatitudes.

verses.text: Do not seek what is too difficult for you; do not examine too closely what is beyond your understanding.
verses.comment: A call to contentment and trust in God’s mysteries. This introduces the tradition of accepting God’s revelation through faith.

verses.text: Reflect on what has been commanded you, for what is hidden is not your concern.
verses.comment: We are called to obey God’s revealed law without presumption, trusting what He has not revealed.

verses.text: Do not meddle in matters beyond your tasks, for what is too much for you is not to be seen.
verses.comment: Humility involves keeping to one’s role; not claiming authority or knowledge not given.

verses.text: For many are the things humans strive for, but illusion has led them astray.
verses.comment: Worldly pursuits are ultimately vain unless submitted to God’s will (cf. Eccl. 12:13).

verses.text: A stubborn heart will be burdened with troubles; and the sinner adds sin to sin.
verses.comment: Obstinacy leads to compounded guilt, highlighting the need for grace and repentance.

verses.text: The punishment of the arrogant has no cure, for the seed of evil takes root in them.
verses.comment: Habitual pride sets against God and leads to ruin.

verses.text: The heart of the prudent reflects on parables; the attentive ear is the desire of the wise.
verses.comment: A wisdom literature principle: spiritual truth is grasped by humble seeking—fulfilled in Christ’s teaching in parables.

verses.text: Water quenches a flaming fire, and charity atones for sins.
verses.comment: Here, acts of love are linked to the forgiveness of sins. The New Testament further develops this in teaching on charity and mercy (Matt. 25:31–46; 1 Pet. 4:8).

verses.text: He who gives favor returns after receiving; he finds support in time of need.
verses.comment: Mercy and generosity are rewarded by God—Jesus himself promises this in the Sermon on the Mount.

verses.text: Whoever seeks the Lord will find acceptance, and his prayer will reach to the clouds.
verses.comment: A promise that those who truly seek God are heard—connecting faith, prayer, and divine favor as seen throughout both Testaments.
